intro: Carex flava subsp. brachyrrhyncha, commonly known as the narrow-panicle sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with triangular stems. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, typically found in dense clusters. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands, meadows, and along stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
